Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Methods for Ice Sheet Projections using Large Non-Gaussian Space-Time Data Sets and Complex Computer Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to study the past, current, and future behavior of the Antarctic ice sheet by using novel statistical methods for combining information from both state-of-the-art ice sheet models and observational data. Ice sheet models such as the PSU 3D ice sheet model may be used to understand the interplay between the processes that drive the behavior of the Antarctic ice sheet. They can also be used to project the future behavior of the ice sheet, which is of great interest in projections of climate change, particularly sea level rise. Learning about future sea-level rise is important not only to scientists but also policymakers. This interdisciplinary research project combines expertise in statistical methodology, ice sheet modeling, computing, and forcing scenarios.

Because ice sheet model outputs are high-dimensional, non-Gaussian, and spatio-temporal, existing approaches for computer model emulation and calibration either do not apply or are computationally infeasible. It is challenging to build computationally expedient methods that are flexible enough to utilize all the information in large data sets and account for uncertainties, complicated errors, and dependencies. We will develop new statistical models and algorithms to address this challenge. Our statistical methodology will build upon Markov random field models (Gaussian and non-Gaussian), composite likelihood and related likelihood approximation methods, and principal components methods generalized to exponential families. The objectives are twofold: (i) developing new statistical and computational methods for emulation (stochastic approximation) of and calibration (input parameter learning) for complex computer models with high-dimensional non-Gaussian space-time data, and (ii) learning the major scientific processes driving the behavior of the Antarctic ice sheet and making projections for ice retreat in this region in the future using, for the first time in this context, information from geologic data over the past 20,000 years. We will focus on the Amundsen Sea Sector of West Antarctica, which contains the rapidly retreating and thinning Pine Island and Thwaites Glaciers; this sector is currently the largest Antarctic contributor to sea-level rise and is considered particularly vulnerable to drastic future retreat. Rigorous statistical comparisons of our ice-sheet model versus geologic data in this sector during the deglacial recession of the last 20,000 years will yield more robust and confident predictions of further future retreat. We will also explore sensitivity of Antarctic ice sheet response to atmosphere-ocean processes as driven by scenarios estimated from coupled earth system models. The processes driving the regional ice sheet will be investigated within the components of the Community Earth System Model (CESM). Ice sheet melting influences sea level rise and can have major impacts on human and ecological systems. Hence, understanding them is paramount to scientists and policy makers. The statistical methodology and computational tools developed here will be widely applicable across a range of disciplines where computer models with high-dimensional output are common; these fields include ecology, hydrology, mechanical engineering, and astronomy. Our efficient methods and software will allow us (and others) to routinely fit more sophisticated models to larger data sets than currently feasible, thus using as much information as possible when drawing scientific conclusions. This will allow for reduced uncertainties, thereby turning the size of the data sets into an asset.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What is the current state of the Antarctic ice sheet? What is its future? This project has worked toward developing methods to improve our understanding of ice sheets. There are three main pieces to the puzzle: first, a detailed understanding of ice sheet physics, describing how the ice sheet evolves over time. This is done via mathematical equations translated into computer code that simulates the ice sheet’s behavior under different conditions. Second, new statistical models that allow us to combine information from ice sheet physics with observations of the ice sheet, and, third, novel computing approaches that make it possible to carry out the calculations necessary for the physical modeling and statistical analysis. In order to work on all three aspects, the research team brings together statisticians, ice sheet modeling experts, and atmospheric scientists.

 

Even though the physics of ice sheets is fairly well understood, some important parameters of the physical model, for example the slipperiness of the ice sheet bed, are not fully known. These parameters can change the behavior of the ice sheet. The project developed new statistical methods to learn about such parameters using ice sheet observations. One of the important scientific findings of the project is that it is possible to meaningfully learn about important parameters of the ice sheet model from geological data and recent satellite data. This helps us to learn about the past behavior of the ice sheet. Also, once we learn about these parameters, we can meaningfully narrow down our projections about how much the ice sheet will contribute to future sea level rise. Our project also examined the complicated relationship between various atmospheric and oceanic variables and the extent to which the ice sheet will retreat over time, particularly the fact that interannual variations in these variables can result in an increase in the retreat of the ice sheet. This suggests that in order to carefully study the behavior of the ice sheet, it is important to include the impact of climate variability, not just smoothed (averaged) climate behavior.

 

There are many statistical methods developed in this project that can be useful for problems beyond studying ice sheets. The methods for learning about model parameters, called model calibration, are very widely applicable to a large number of problems in science and engineering, and other disciplines where sophisticated models are used. In many scientific disciplines, observations are in the form of spatial data (data that have locations attached to them) that are non-Gaussian. Ice sheet presence-absence data are an example of non-Gaussian spatial data. We have developed multiple new computational algorithms for analyzing such data, based on finding an optimal "projection-based" way to reduce the dimension of the problem; our algorithms show promise in being much more efficient than previous algorithms, and could thereby allow for the analyses of larger data sets than feasible before. We have also developed algorithms for an important class of problems called models with intractable normalizing functions; this work has broad applications outside of atmospheric sciences as well.

 

Two women received PhDs based on their work on this project, one in statistics and the other in atmospheric sciences. In addition to becoming experts in their subject matter, they also became proficient in working across disciplines, which is very important for addressing challenging scientific questions like the ones in this project, as well as in many other scientific areas. This project supported three undergraduates who worked on related research. The undergraduates have successfully completed their degrees and either gained employment or gone on to prestigious graduate schools. The investigators have published several papers and given numerous talks on the subjects in this project, so the impact of the ideas will extend well beyond those directly involved with this research.
